Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: A Memory based account of cue generation and predictive inference

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
Research in decision-making has increasingly focused on the use of heuristics, or short cuts, to describe judgment and decision-making, such as recent work on rationality and fast-and-frugal heuristics. The central purpose of research on fast-and-frugal heuristics is to characterize the various strategies that people employ across a variety of decision tasks, with the goal of understanding the interplay between task structure and strategy use. At the same time, other work in judgment and decision-making has begun exploring the interrelationship between basic-level cognitive processes such as attention and memory and higher-level processes involved in decision-making. For example, recent work illustrates that theoretical models based on long-term memory and working-memory are important for understanding judgment and decision making in a variety of real-world domains, such as medical diagnosis and intelligence analysis. The overarching goal of the present research is to integrate the fast-and-frugal heuristics approach with a judgment model based on basic memory theory. The researchers' goal is to address, both empirically and theoretically, how basic memory processes such as long-term memory and working memory both enable and constrain the use of fast-and-frugal heuristics. The resulting theoretical and empirical research will advance fundamental theory broadly in the area of judgment and decision making.

Research on fast-and-frugal heuristics has been amongst the most influential and widely cited work within the area of judgment and decision-making over the past few decades. However, despite the proliferation of research on fast-and-frugal heuristics, aspects of the framework remain somewhat ill-defined. In particular, while the framework relies extensively on constructs from the area of memory, relatively little theoretical and empirical work has pursued this aspect of heuristic functioning. Yet, this is an important component of most real-world judgment and choice tasks, as the input to the decision process often relies upon the output of memory. The proposed work aims to address this gap in the literature by systematically investigating the role of memory in cue-based inference tasks where heuristics such as Take-the-best are assumed to operate. In addition to the project's contribution to the empirical literature, this work will break new ground on theoretical models of decision-making by merging fast-and-frugal heuristics with a memory-processes model of hypothesis generation and judgment. The proposed experiments will provide a detailed analysis of the underlying memory processes that both enable and constrain memory-based inference. The knowledge gained from this research has the potential to impact decision making in applied contexts such as risk communication and medicine, where heuristic rules are implemented as decision aids.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The research funded under this project produced three primary outcomes. First, we have made enormous progress in understanding how people make decisions in contexts in which they are trying to predict a future outcome, such as the future price of a stock or a decision related to student learning. Second, we have successfully integrated research within behavioral decision making with research in the education literature to develop simple interventions aimed at enhancing student learning.  Third, we have developed a reproducibility pipeline for enhancing the transparency and reproducibility of our research.

In regard to the first outcome, our research indicates that memory-retrieval processes strongly influence decision making. The important message to be gleaned from our work is that biases in decision making can manifest as a function of memory. The implication of this work is that shortcomings in decision making may require addressing shortcomings in memory. In layman's terms, a poor decision may be symptomatic of a poor memory, and not necessarily reflect a poor decision strategy.

In regard to the second outcome, we have begun applying lessons from the behavioral decision making literature to educationally relevant contexts. Specifically, our research shows that how students decide what information to focus on when preparing for an exam can be 'nudged' by having participants make different types of metacognitive judgments. Moreover, different types of metacognitive judgments alter the information (i.e., cues) that students use to make decisions about what to study. Testing of these 'nudges' is ongoing and we hope to determine whether the nudges lead to long-term improvements in learning outcomes.

In regard to the third outcome, we have been developing a reproducibility pipeline within the lab to ensure that all of our research is reproducible. Our pipeline addresses several issues that have been identified as problematic in scholarly research within the scientific research community. Our pipeline entails internally conducted replication experiments; duplicative data analyses completed by multiple individuals independently; preregistration of experiments (where feasible) and replications; and public disclosure of data, analysis code, and all study material.

The funded work has led to several broader impact outcomes. First, the funded research has enabled us to train the next generation of scientists on the value of open science methods, transparency, and reproducibility. Two graduate students, 2 post-docs, and over 16 undergraduate students have benefitted from this training. Second, we have also implemented a pedagogy-inspired replication system for our undergraduate students. In addition to assisting with research projects within the lab, students also complete their own replication project. These replications are intended for publication, so not only will students gain valuable research skills and training in reproducibility, but they will also have an opportunity to submit their research for publication.
